tit.e: Kani Official Rank System of Ancient Japan
Kani Official Rank System of Ancient Japan
Kani Official Rank System of Ancient Japan

sen.j: 官位（かんい）とは、位階の事。
sen.e: Kani means Ikai (Court rank).
Kani means Ikai (Court rank).
Kani means Ikai (Court rank).

sen.j: 官職を各々相当する位階に配して等級を定めることを官位相当という。
sen.e: The system for deciding rank by distributing government positions according to corresponding Ikai court rank was called Kani matching.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The system for deciding government officials' ranks by matching up each government position to the corresponding Ikai court rank was referred to as Kanisoto (Kani matching).
sen.cmt: 分かりやすくなるよう、表現を補足、修正しました。
sen.e: The system for deciding government officials' ranks by matching up each government position to the corresponding Ikai court rank was referred to as Kanisoto (Kani matching).

sen.j: 位階によって相当する官職に任命する制度を官位制（官位制度、官位相当制）という。
sen.e: Appointing someone to a government position matching his Ikai was called Kani official rank system or Kanisoto sei (the ranks of the bureaucracy system of the ritsuryo system).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The system to appoint someone a government position that matches his Ikai was called the Kani official rank system or Kanisoto-sei.
sen.cmt: （）内の官位相当制の訳はここでは不適ですし、文中で説明されているので削除しました。
sen.e: The system to appoint someone a government position that matches his Ikai was called the Kani official rank system or Kanisoto-sei.

sen.j: 日本において、官位制は、律令法（律令制）によって体系的に整備された。
sen.e: In Japan, the Kani official rank system was systematically improved by Ritsuryo law (the Ritsuryo system).
In Japan, the Kani official rank system was systematically improved by Ritsuryo law (the Ritsuryo system).
In Japan, the Kani official rank system was systematically improved by Ritsuryo law (the Ritsuryo system).

sen.j: なお、「官職」と「位階」を一緒にした、例えば「従五位下越前守」と云う名称をさして官位と云う場合があるが、誤用である。
sen.e: It is incorrect to put a government post and the Ikai court rank together and call it Kani: i.e. "Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) Echizen no kuni no kami (Governor of Echizen Province)."
It is incorrect to put a government post and the Ikai court rank together and call it Kani: i.e. "Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) Echizen no kuni no kami (Governor of Echizen Province)."
It is incorrect to put a government post and the Ikai court rank together and call it Kani: i.e. "Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) Echizen no kuni no kami (Governor of Echizen Province)."

sen.j: この場合は官職は越前守で、官位は従五位下である。
sen.e: For this, the government post is Echizen no kuni no kami and the Kani is Jugoinoge.
For this, the government post is Echizen no kuni no kami and the Kani is Jugoinoge.
For this, the government post is Echizen no kuni no kami and the Kani is Jugoinoge.

sen.j: 位階制度については「位階」の項目を、官職については「日本の官制」を参照のこと。
sen.e: For Ikai system, see the section of "Ikai" and for government posts, see "Government Posts of Japan."
sen.cmt: 「日本の官制」について訳されている方の訳語と統一が必要です。
sen.e: For the Ikai system, see the section of "Ikai" and for government posts, see "Government Posts of Japan."
sen.cmt: 冠詞を補いました。訳語の統一を（左記）お願いします。
sen.e: For the Ikai system, see the section of "Ikai" and for government posts, see "Government Posts of Japan."

sen.j: 以下、日本における官位制について概説する。
sen.e: Below is the explanation about Kani official rank system of Japan.
Below is the explanation about the Kani official rank system of Japan.
Below is the explanation about the Kani official rank system of Japan.

tit.e: Summary of Kani Official Rank System
Summary of Kani Official Rank System
Summary of Kani Official Rank System

sen.j: 官位制は、中国から他の政治行政制度と共に継受され、日本で独自の発展を遂げた。
sen.e: Kani official rank system first came from China, with other political administrative systems, but was developed in its own way in Japan.
The Kani official rank system first came from China along with other political administrative systems, but was developed in its own way in Japan.
The Kani official rank system first came from China along with other political administrative systems, but was developed in its own way in Japan.

sen.j: 官吏を序列化する制度は、603年（推古天皇11年）の冠位十二階に始まり、その後数度の変遷を経る（冠位・官位制度の変遷）。
sen.e: The system of grading government officials started in 603 with Kani Junikai (The Twelve Level Cap and Rank System) and went through several changes after that (see the section on The Change of Kani Systems).
sen.cmt: 『冠位・官位制度の変遷』の項を翻訳されている方の表現と統一が必要です。
sen.e: The system of grading government officials started in 603 with Kani Junikai (The Twelve Level Cap and Rank System) and went through several changes after that (see the section on The Change of Kani Systems).

The system of grading government officials started in 603 with Kani Junikai (The Twelve Level Cap and Rank System) and went through several changes after that (see the section on The Change of Kani Systems).

sen.j: そして、701年（大宝 (日本)元年）に成立した大宝律令と、718年（養老2年）に成立した養老律令には、それぞれ『官位令』という令があり、これにより官位制は確立した。
sen.e: Both Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code) set in 701 and Yoro Ritsuryo (Yoro Code) have a code called "Kani Code" (Court ranking law) and with these codes, the Kani official rank system was established.
Both Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code) set in 701 and Yoro Ritsuryo (Yoro Code) in 718 included a law called "Kani Law" (Court Ranking Law), and the Kani official rank system was established by this law.
sen.cmt: 官位令は「Court ranking law」なので、令の訳はlawとした方が良いと思います。
sen.e: Both Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code) set in 701 and Yoro Ritsuryo (Yoro Code) in 718 included a law called "Kani Law" (Court Ranking Law), and the Kani official rank system was established by this law.

sen.j: 官位令によれば、位階は、皇族には一品（いっぽん）～四品（しほん）の品位（ほんい）4階があり、諸臣は正一位少初位下の30階があった。
sen.e: According to the Kani court ranking law, for the Imperial Family, there were four levels of Ikai from Ippon (First Order of an Imperial Prince) to Shihon (the fourth-ranked Imperial Prince) and other officials had 30 levels from Shoichii (Senior First Rank) to Shosoige (the lowest court rank).
sen.cmt: 原本より「一品（～）四品」と「～」を追加。
sen.e: According to the Kani court ranking law, for the Imperial Family, there were four levels of Ikai from Ippon (the highest rank given to an Imperial prince) to Shihon (the fourth rank given to an Imperial prince) and other officials had 30 levels from Shoichii (Senior First Rank) to Shosoige (the lowest court rank).
sen.cmt: 一品と四品の訳は表現を統一するべきと思うので、Ippon/Shihon (the highest/fourth rank given to an Imperial prince)としました。
sen.e: According to the Kani court ranking law, for the Imperial Family, there were four levels of Ikai from Ippon (the highest rank given to an Imperial prince) to Shihon (the fourth rank given to an Imperial prince) and other officials had 30 levels from Shoichii (Senior First Rank) to Shosoige (the lowest court rank).

sen.j: 官位制は、位階と官職を関連付けて任命することにより、官職の世襲を排して適材適所の人材登用を進めることを目的とした。
sen.e: By appointing someone by connecting his Ikai and government position, the purpose of the Kani official rank system was, to avoid heredity posts and to employ the most suitable person for each position.

The purpose of the Kani official rank system was to avoid the heredity of government positions and to employ the most suitable person for each position by appointing him a position in connection with his Ikai.

The purpose of the Kani official rank system was to avoid the heredity of government positions and to employ the most suitable person for each position by appointing him a position in connection with his Ikai.

sen.j: しかし、高位者の子孫には一定以上の位階に叙位する制度（蔭位の制）を設けるなど、当初からその目的は達成困難なものであった。
sen.e: However, it was not easy to attain this goal from the beginning because some systems were set up to give priority to the descendants of men of high rank to get promotion easily, such as Oni no sei (the automatic promotion of people at the age of 21, whose parents are from Imperial Prince down to the fifth rank, or whose grandparents are higher than the third rank).
sen.cmt: 「蔭位の制」の説明部分を多少変更しました。
sen.e: However, it was not easy to attain this goal from the beginning because some systems, such as Oni no sei (the automatic promotion of people at the age of 21, whose parents were from Imperial Prince down to the fifth rank, or whose grandparents were higher than the third rank), were set up to give priority to the descendants of men of high rank to get promotion easily.
sen.cmt: such as Oni no seiはsystemsの後においた方が自然かと思いました。（）内の説明文の時制を統一しました。
sen.e: However, it was not easy to attain this goal from the beginning because some systems, such as Oni no sei (the automatic promotion of people at the age of 21, whose parents were from Imperial Prince down to the fifth rank, or whose grandparents were higher than the third rank), were set up to give priority to the descendants of men of high rank to get promotion easily.

sen.j: 官位制自体は、形骸化されつつも明治時代に律令法が廃止されるまで続いた。
sen.e: Although losing its significance, the Ikai court rank system itself lasted until Ritsuryo law was abolished in Meiji Period.
Although losing its significance, the Ikai court rank system itself lasted until Ritsuryo law was abolished in the Meiji Period.
Although losing its significance, the Ikai court rank system itself lasted until Ritsuryo law was abolished in the Meiji Period.

sen.j: また、位階制度は、その後変遷を重ねながらも栄典制度のひとつとして、現在に至るまで存続する。
sen.e: In fact, the Ikai court rank system still exists after changing its function to that of awarding honors.
In fact, the Ikai court rank system still exists after changing its function to one of the systems of awarding honors.
In fact, the Ikai court rank system still exists after changing its function to one of the systems of awarding honors.

tit.e: Contents of the Kani Official Rank System
Contents of the Kani Official Rank System
Contents of the Kani Official Rank System

sen.j: 官職と位階の対応には、幅がある。
sen.e: There are a range of government positions with matching Ikai rank.
There are a range of government positions which match particular Ikai ranks.
Mapping between government positions and Ikai ranks is not necessarily fixed.

sen.j: また、時代によって官位相当も変化する。
sen.e: The Kani matching changed over times.
The Kani matching changed over times.
The Kani matching changed over times.

sen.j: 下位の位階の者が官位相当よりも高位の官職に就く場合を守といい、高位の位階の者が官位相当よりも下位の官職に就く場合を行という。
sen.e: When a man with a low Ikai got a higher level job than his matching Kani, it was called Shu and when a high Ikai man got lower level job than his matching Kani, it was called Ko.
The case where a man with a low Ikai got a job of a higher level than his Ikai was called Shu, and that where a man got a job of a lower level than his Ikai was called Ko.
sen.cmt: Itのさすものが曖昧になっていると思うので、the caseで置き換えました。
sen.e: The case where a man with a low Ikai got a job of a higher level than his Ikai was called Shu, and that where a man got a job of a lower level than his Ikai was called Ko.

sen.j: また、叙位されたものの官職に就かないことを散位あるいは無官という。
sen.e: When a man was offered a position but declined it, it was called Sani or Mukan.
The case where a man was offered but declined a position was called Sani or Mukan.
sen.cmt: Itのさすものが曖昧になっていると思うので、the caseで置き換えました。
sen.e: The case where a man was offered but declined a position was called Sani or Mukan.

sen.j: 従五位下以上と六位の蔵人は、昇殿を許されたために殿上人、太政官のうち従三位以上もしくは参議のことを公卿と呼んだ。
sen.e: Kurodo (imperial archives keepers) of Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) and above and Rokui (Sixth Rank) were called Tenjobito (a high-ranking courtier allowed into the Imperial Palace) because they had access to the imperial court; and Daijokan (Grand Councils of State) of Jusani (Junior Third Rank) and over and Sangi (councilors) were called Kugyo (high court nobles).

High officials of Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) and above and Kurodo (imperial archives keepers) of Rokui (Sixth Rank) were called Tenjobito (a high-ranking courtier allowed into the Imperial Palace) because they had access to the imperial court; and the Daijokan (Grand Councils of State) members of Jusani (Junior Third Rank) and higher and Sangi (councilors) were called Kugyo (high court nobles).
sen.cmt: 原文の意味の取り方ですが、殿上人は「従五位下以上の官人及び六位の蔵人」とするべきでないかと思います。また、太政官は機関のなで個人の役職名ではないと思いますので、the Daijokan membersとするべきではないかと思います。
sen.e: High officials of Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) and above and Kurodo (imperial archives keepers) of Rokui (Sixth Rank) were called Tenjobito (a high-ranking courtier allowed into the Imperial Palace) because they had access to the imperial court; and the Daijokan (Grand Councils of State) members of Jusani (Junior Third Rank) and higher and Sangi (councilors) were called Kugyo (high court nobles).

sen.j: 五位に昇ることを叙爵、冠（こうぶり）賜る、という。
sen.e: Moving to Goi (Fifth Rank) was called joshaku (conferring a peerage), or koburitamawaru (receiving a crown).
Moving up to Goi (Fifth Rank) was termed joshaku (receiving a peerage), or koburi-tamawaru (receiving a crown).
sen.cmt: この文中では、叙爵はconferringではなくreceivingとするべきと思います。
sen.e: Moving up to Goi (Fifth Rank) was termed joshaku (receiving a peerage), or koburi-tamawaru (receiving a crown).

sen.j: 俸給は、原則として位階に対して支給される。
sen.e: Remuneration was basically paid according to their Ikai.
Remuneration was basically paid according to their Ikai.
Remuneration was basically paid according to their Ikai.

sen.j: そのため、異なる官職に就いていても、位階が同じならば同じ俸給であった。
sen.e: So, even if they had different positions but their Ikai was the same, their remuneration was the same, too.
So, those who had different positions but ranked with the same Ikai would be paid equal remuneration.
sen.cmt: 分かりやすくなるよう、表現を修正しました。
sen.e: So, those who had different positions but ranked with the same Ikai would be paid equal remuneration.

sen.j: 平安時代以降には、皇族・公卿など高い身分にある者、または、上級の官職や博士など官職に対しても、俸給が支給されるようになった。
sen.e: During the Heian Period and later, men in higher positions such as the Imperial Family and Kugyo, as well as upper ranked government officials and Hakushi (Doctors), were also receiving remuneration.

During the Heian Period and later, men in higher positions such as the Imperial Family and Kugyo, as well as upper ranked government officials and Hakase (Professors), were also receiving remuneration.
sen.cmt: 博士は「hakase」と読むようです。
sen.e: During the Heian Period and later, men in higher positions such as the Imperial Family and Kugyo, as well as upper ranked government officials and Hakase (Professors), were also receiving remuneration.

sen.j: その他、国司には俸給の他に国司としての収入があった。
sen.e: Kokushi (provincial governors) had other income as Kokushi as well as their official remuneration.
Kokushi (provincial governors) were allowed an additional income as Kokushi as well as the remuneration paid by the government.
sen.cmt: 文法を修正し、言葉を少し補いました。
sen.e: Kokushi (provincial governors) were allowed an additional income as Kokushi as well as the remuneration paid by the government.

tit.e: Changes in Kani Official Rank System
Changes in Kani Official Rank System
Changes in Kani Official Rank System

sen.j: 官職は奈良時代に法文化された当時はその本来の意味を有していたが、平安時代に入ると新しく血脈的な尊卑をも表現するようになり、ひいては家格の象徴となり、国家的な意味はほとんどなくなってしまう。
sen.e: In the Nara Period, when government posts were put into statutory form, they had their original function but when the Heian Period began, they started to represent lineage, aristocrat and plebeian, and they became symbols of their Kakaku (family status) and lost its national meaning.

At the time when government posts were put into statutory form in the Nara Period, they kept their original meanings, but in the Heian Period, they started to represent high or low lineage as well and became symbols of Kakaku (family status), and lost their national meanings.
sen.cmt: 「国家的な意味」が理解しづらく、直訳で訳しています。
sen.e: At the time when government posts were put into statutory form in the Nara Period, they kept their original meanings, but in the Heian Period, they started to represent high or low lineage as well and became symbols of Kakaku (family status), and lost the original meaning as government posts of Japan.
sen.cmt: 「国家的な意味」をtheir national meanings. →the original meaning as government posts of Japanとしました。

sen.j: 本来、官職はその国家的仕事に直結し、自己の身分を示すのは位階であったが、官職が身分や家柄を示すようになったため、官位相当という令制以来の原則にも変化が現れ始めた。
sen.e: Originally, government posts were directly connected to national jobs and it was Ikai which showed their social status; but because the posts started to mean their social and family status, changes began to show in the fundamental rules of Kani matching that had existed since the beginning of the Ritsuryo system (system of centralized governance, in Japan: esp. 7th-10th century).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Originally, government posts were directly connected with national jobs and it was Ikai that showed their social status; but because the posts started to symbolize their social and family status, the fundamental rules of Kanisoto (Kani matching), which had existed since the beginning of the Ritsuryo system (the system of centralized administration established under the Ritsuryo codes), started to change.
sen.cmt: 「国家的仕事」の意が理解しづらく、直訳のままにしてありますが、これで意味が通るかご確認ください。分かりやすくなるよう、表現を補足、修正しました。
sen.e: Originally, government posts were directly connected with national jobs and it was Ikai that showed their social status; but because the posts started to symbolize their social and family status, the fundamental rules of Kanisoto (Kani matching), which had existed since the beginning of the Ritsuryo system (the system of centralized administration established under the Ritsuryo codes), started to change.

sen.j: 江戸時代末期に至るまで官職と位階は身分や家格を示す標準となり、宮廷生活における権威を持っていた。
sen.e: The posts and Ikai were the standard to show social and family status and had strong authority in court life until the end of Edo Period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The posts and Ikai were the standard to show social and family status and had strong authority in court life until the end of Edo Period.
The posts and Ikai were the standard to show social and family status and had strong authority in court life until the end of Edo Period.

sen.e: See below.
